messages: 69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (02:18): content-types for binary formats baffle me
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (02:18): or rather, the way people defend them baffles me
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (02:18): (re: the e-mail i'm about to send out replying to a long thread about video mime types last august)
e0563cc2e83070e74ce7019226dd654d (02:19): it's taken you this long to formulate a response, or you wished to see the opinion(s) of others
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (02:23): neither
ad7340c0d2664b131f969961d78c86b2 (02:23): 69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e: hey, did you ever say anything about kaazing and how they supposedly invented websockets as they stand at present?
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (02:23): no idea
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (02:24): not sure how they stand at present, in fact :-)
ad7340c0d2664b131f969961d78c86b2 (02:24): "Kaazing basically invented the protocol as it stands now." - Ian Hickson, Google & HTML5 Author
ad7340c0d2664b131f969961d78c86b2 (02:24): http://www.kaazing.com/about/index.html
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (02:25): ad7340c0d2664b131f969961d78c86b2: http://krijnhoetmer.nl/irc-logs/whatwg/20100131#l-223
ad7340c0d2664b131f969961d78c86b2 (02:25): looks like they like their patents too; as they seem to be pushing for one relating to using backwards compat. protocols with websockets
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (02:25): (later, http://krijnhoetmer.nl/irc-logs/whatwg/20100131#l-241 )
ad7340c0d2664b131f969961d78c86b2 (02:26): 69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e: right, so, it's a pretty big mis-guided quote
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (02:26): how so?
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (02:26): note that the hybi group has basically totally revamped the protocol, so it's kind of a moot point now
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (02:26): as the protocol is nothing like it was then
ad7340c0d2664b131f969961d78c86b2 (02:26): well, the way it reads on their site it's like they are claiming to have invented the protocol as it is at present
ad7340c0d2664b131f969961d78c86b2 (02:27): but there's really a heap more people who have contributed to it
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (02:27): oh, yeah, their site might be misleading *shrug*
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (02:27): really at this point i don't know what the spec looks like
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (02:27): but there aren't that many people who have contributed
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (02:27): er, who had contributed
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (02:27): at the time
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (02:28): isn't the group basically going to do the design abarth proposed now?
ad7340c0d2664b131f969961d78c86b2 (02:28): 69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e: i think so, there are still some against it
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (02:28): as i understand it there are three realistic handshake designs: tls-only, the one i designed based on mcarter's design, and abarth's design
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (02:28): but i'm not really following the work closely, so don't take my word for it
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (02:31): anyone know if annevk is still worknig on the fullscreen cssom thing?
65325d50b2e25aca54bc871b89758c9c (02:32): 69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e: at this point, I don't think the one you designed is secure
65325d50b2e25aca54bc871b89758c9c (02:32): and therefore not realistic
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (02:32): the one with the eight bytes is still secure according to abarth (i spoke to him just earlier today about it)
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (02:32): what his group tested was the upgrade without the 8 bytes
a11aabeeceeae6b8cb5d12ea06b56554 (02:33): What eight bytes?
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (02:33): (which we knew wasn't secure; the 8 bytes were mitigation for that)
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (02:33): a11aabeeceeae6b8cb5d12ea06b56554: key3
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (02:33): and the server's response
65325d50b2e25aca54bc871b89758c9c (02:34): I wouldn't interpret that as "still secure"
65325d50b2e25aca54bc871b89758c9c (02:34): they didn't test one way or the other whether the 8 bytes help, or whether there is a way to work around whatever they do
65325d50b2e25aca54bc871b89758c9c (02:35): however, I still think it is less robust against a variety of threat models than the adam+eric proposal
65325d50b2e25aca54bc871b89758c9c (02:35): at this point I wouldn't really trust it
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (02:36): well i am not advocating it one way or the other
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (02:36): so that's fine :-)
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (02:36): i'm not aware of any attack though, even theoretical

65325d50b2e25aca54bc871b89758c9c (02:41): its security against this intercepting proxy attack depends completely on whether the 8 random bytes break the ability to get intercepting proxies to see subsequent data on the connection as new requests
65325d50b2e25aca54bc871b89758c9c (02:42): (something that Adam et al didn't test but probably should have)

69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (02:48): 65325d50b2e25aca54bc871b89758c9c: note that for there to be any subsequent data, the 8 bytes have to make it to the server and back to the client; note also that there's no way to distinguish the 8 bytes from the subsequent bytes, so if the 8 bytes get to the server, it seems highly unlikely that the remainder don't either. But indeed, we don't know without testing.
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (02:48): It's academic, anyway, since the group isn't going to use this handshake.
65325d50b2e25aca54bc871b89758c9c (02:48): well, it's still the handshake in current drafts
65325d50b2e25aca54bc871b89758c9c (02:49): what's surprisingly hard is convince the group of the merits of the CONNECT handshake
